reviewText: I was sixteen years old when I first saw this film in 1958.  During the first half, the audience (including myself) was slightly confused. We really didn't understand where the film was heading. At the point where "Judy" is introduced, I believe most people really believed she was another person.  At the end, when the nun enters the tower, "I hear voices,"-- resulting in Judy jumping to her death--the audience went wild.  There were loud screams, booing, and lots of negative shouting (some I can't repeat here).The audience really believed they had been duped by Hitchcock, and they were furious.  As I look back to this time, I now realize that in the decade of the fifties, American audiences were not familiar with the idea of "suspended reality" as were French and German film enthusiasts.  When the truth came out at the end of the film, the audience felt cheated when they realized Hitchcock tricked them all along by making them believe......(spoiler).To answer the comments left by other viewers.  Yes, the pacing was slow in some parts, but this was Hitchcock's style--he wanted to draw the viewer into the life of Madeleine's world.  Closely watch the film again and you should discover (spoiler) that Scotty unwittingly has been drawn into this tangled web of deception when he meets an old college friend who now manages a shipyard in San Francisco. Most of the film is a lie from this point forward.  The audience doesn't know this since they like the affable, pleasant Jimmy Stewart. The viewer accepts and believes Stewart's actions--but all along both are being fooled.Adding to the mystery, foreboding and beauty of this masterpiece, is Bernard Herrmann's glorious score.  I wonder how Hitchcock felt when he first heard it?  I can't remember when a movie score complemented a film as well as this haunting and beautiful score.I have read that Hitchcock once said after viewing San Francisco for the first time in 1950, "I'm going to make a movie here someday."  Well it took him eight years and he and his team beautifully photographed this great city.

reviewText: I saw this movie at the ripe old age of 7 or 8 when it was originally released. At the time, I was a total Kim Novak fanatic. My aunt knew her secretary and my violet bedroom was plastered with autographed Kim pictures and my existence was pure KIM until I saw this movie. Within 5 minutes, I was absolutely glued to the screen and sort of disassociated myself from Novak-mania and got into the story. The plotline had more ups and downs than a roller coaster going full tilt boogie. I was completely sucked into the world of Madeline/Judy. The acting itself was pretty understated, but the story was not. While the plot may have been a little thick for a child, the absolute terror I felt was something you can carry around for a lifetime. I developed a total fear of heights which remains today. Each time I watch it, my toes curl and my knuckles go white as I grip my armrest.The new DVD edition has brought this movie back to its original pristine condition to create the ultimate technicolor nightmare. Forty+ years after its original release, it is amazing just how good this movie still is. While the acting is excellent, the real star of the film is Hitchcock. This is the master at his best. I have two VHS copies, but they are collecting dust. If you want to experience ultimate Vertigo, buy this DVD. Just wonderful.As for all the critics who dissed this film at its original release-----BAH! This will go down as one of the Hitchcock's best!
summary: Hitch, You Just Keep Me Hangin' On

reviewText: I have heard people talk about great movies, saying, "I envy the person who is seeing this for the first time, because I'll never get to relive the pure awe I felt then."  Well, that was me, seeing Vertigo for the first time.  Pure awe.  I, of course, being a film fan, had heard people laud this as Hitchcock's best film.  But I would scoff and say "pshaw" go back and watch The Lady Vanishes again, or Shadow of a Doubt.I really had no idea what I was missing.This is a fascinating film.  Not only because of the surprises thrown at you, but also because of the performances.  Jimmy Stewart is cast against type (although he is still the everyman we identify with) as a man obsessed with a woman he fell in love with, and then lost to a bizarre suicide.  Kim Novak is perfect as well in her dual role as the suicidal woman and her lookalike that Stewart sees walking along the street some days after and takes up with.If you haven't seen it, I won't say any more, so as not to ruin the twists and surprises.  I will say, however, that if you like Hitchcock, you should definitely add this one to your list.If you are renting it, make sure to get the Widescreen version.  It does make a difference.

reviewText: Vertigo (1958)Directed:  Alfred HitchcockScreenplay: Alec Coppel and Samuel Taylor, adapted from Pierre Boileau's and Thomas Narcejac's novel, D'entre les mortesDirector of Photography: Robert Burks, A.S.C. (Vista Vision)Music: Bernard HerrmannWith:  James Stewart (John "Scottie" Ferguson)Kim Novak (Madeleine/Judy)Barbara Bel Geddes (Midge)Tom Helmore (Gavin Elster)Henry Jones (the Coroner)When Vertigo came out in 1958, its reception of by both audiences and critics was lukewarm ("Another Hitchcock-and-bull story," wrote Time magazine ) and the film languished in relative obscurity for decades, until it came to new life thanks to a restored version in 1996,  which was subsequently theatrically re-released with VHS, laser and DVD editions following. Renewed interest brought new accolades, and, for one, Martin Scorsese, an admirer of Vertigo, marveled at the ability of Hitchcock, still working within the studio system, "to create such a personal story," to actually do the work of an auteur,  that is, a work that satisfies an artistic concept rather one to appeal to a broader audience. In a survey of its contributors and readers, Senses of Cinema proclaimed Vertigo the number one greatest film ever.  Today Vertigo is considered Hitchcock's masterpiece, the film that above others is expressive of the Master's visual art, what he called "pure cinema." The fact that "Sight ane Sound" placed this film as the Number 1, displacing "Citizen Kane," which had held this position for decades, is a significant sign of the changing currents of film criticism. That does not mean that criticism must stop moving, and accept this placement, just because SOME critics made a ceratin decision. Especially in film criticism; which, as Andrew Sarris noted, is a criss-cross of antogonistic currents, rather than a building block of historical assessments. That does not mean that there should be a universal agreement on everything; that would not be criticism; but neither does it mean that one should conceal one's views, just because one goes against the current.In view of such praise and admiration for a film that has stood the test of time, it is hard to find fault, and yet I must admit I never quite liked Vertigo, at least not as much as other Hitchcock films that usually engross me and I want to see them time and again--as I have. Those include most of the great Hitchcock classics of the fifties, like Rear Window (first on my account), To Catch a Thief, The Man Who Knew Too Much, North by Northwest, and even The Wrong Man, a well told true story with Kafkaesque overtones. Of course, there is Psycho and The Birds in the early sixties and Notorious in the mid-forties. What is not to like about these films?  I do not even mention here such early classic Hitchcock's as The Thirty Nine Steps, The Lady Vanishes (both of his English period), and of course Rebecca, Shadow of a Doubt, Suspicion, and Strangers on a Train, all of these being the products of his first decade in Hollywood, of his collaboration with David O. Selznick. Vertigo came during the period of Hitchcock's independence as a producer, and his collaboration with Paramount in the fifties, when he commanded the choice of scripts, actors to use, and pretty much had the supervision of an entire production in his hands. A television show since the mid fifties, had given Hitchcock unprecedented recognition among audiences, and considerable powers--if not dictatorial--in determining how a film project was to be shaped.  Hitchcock had admitted on numerous occasions that his purpose in making a film was audience appeal and that he always had an eye for box office returns.Who could quarrel with this renewed interest and such superlatives? After all, even Hitchcock's most neglected and negligible films (Mr. and Mrs. Smith, 1941) deserve some attention, all being the products of a great master. But since it is an unwritten axiom that any film can receive praise from anybody, and conversely, any film can receive adverse criticism from anyone, even a great masterpiece can be found flawed; and if so, the flaw must be discerned, discussed, and pointed out. Since film is the most popular medium ever (medium, if not art), criticisms by audience who pay money to see films (one way or the other--even TV cable is paying) are not only allowable but recommended. Hitchcock himself would of course be the first to welcome such an idea, for, as we know now, Hitchcock courted audiences like no one else; he wanted to be LIKED above all. It is no accident that he obtruded his rotund persona in miniscule cameos (that everybody expected and no one could miss) in nearly all his films. Call it vanity, but an undeniable fact. Regardless, any film of his or anyone else's is fair game, if the criticism is fair and the points made sufficiently supported. The Roman critic Horace, speaking of Homer,  said that even a great genius can take a nap in a long job of writing. Hitchcock made eight movies in the span of five years,  a fact that may have to account for an occasional lapse. Formal criticism, however, has nothing to do with motives, or personal involvement, but with the product on the page or screen. Why do I have reservations about Vertigo? I have honestly tried to like it, especially since my wife likes it more than I do, and we have watched it together many times on tape and DVD (the restored version). I don't say that I DISLIKE it all that much, but I always find something wanting, and frankly I am a little bored by it. There must be a reason for that--for I adore the Master. But trying to like a film and concealing one's dislike is not good honest criticism, so here I am going to serve what I perceive to be my objections--or reservations. It may not be easy.To come to the point. I have two basic criticisms to make about this film: the persona of the main actor (Stewart) and its manipulation for this role; and the metamorphosis of Kim Novak from Madeleine Elster to Judy Barton; and the general tone of the film (a rather vague point) that belies the rigorous pacing and energy  one sees in most Hitchcock movies.What bothers me most about this film is Jimmy Stewart himself, his persona, and his role, and even his acting itself. Don't misunderstand me. Mr. Stewart is one of my favorite movie actors, and I have liked most of his movies (I can hardly think of some I don't like), for he always appears real, convincing in whatever role he has played, even a rare bad character. He projects emotional honesty, forthrightness, openness--you always know where he stands--even a bit of righteousness, but in a good way. He is the very image of American independence and true grit. He never balks when a moral issue is at stake. He will undertake to protect the innocent and the downtrodden, and he will blow up when human rights are in danger of being abused. Hitchcock saw these charismatic qualities in the actor and used him well in three movies he made with him previous to Vertigo. In Rope (1948), Stewart uncovers a murder; in The Man Who Knew Too Much (1955), he defends his family; and in Rear Window (1954), despite the dubious ethics of peeping on your neighbors, he is motivated by an unselfish desire to actually detect a murderer. For Hitchcock, these were sterling character qualities which gave Stewart his impetus and his appeal as a movie hero, and even his self-righteousness, or tendency to become loud, which Hitchcock brought under control, became assets for Stewart's persona.Most of these qualities are either underplayed or disappear altogether in the character Stewart plays in Vertigo.  As Johnny or "Scottie" Ferguson, Stewart appears passive, vulnerable, and obsessed, displaying some of the characteristics of an anti-hero--which may be suitable for the likes of Marlon Brando, James Dean, or Montgomery Clift. Gone is Stewart's bouncy optimism, sturdy common sense and good humor of the man we see, even under strain, in Rear Window. In that movie, Stewart is often frustrated--and a bit unmannerly--but not morose. though not a detective, he is alerted to see a man carrying a suitcase in the middle of a rainy night, and in a series of non-dialogue, pure cinema scenes, the first suspicion forms, and from that point on, a bored immobile man takes histance that a murder is what he witnessed. I Vertigo we see him first fighting a debilitating fear--acrophobia or fear of heights--which drives him to early retirement as a police detective, and then a strange obsession develops with a mysterious woman, whose husband fears she will kill herself and hires Scottie to protect her. The woman (Kim Novak) is quite attractive and sensuous and no wonder Scottie falls in love with her. When she apparently commits suicide by jumping from a tower, his feelings for the "dead" woman intensify to the point of haunting him for months, until he casually meets a woman in the streets and follows her to her apartment; she is the spitting image of Madeleine, except that her hair is red. He is attracted to her only because she looks like Madeleine, whom he still loves making him something of a necrophilic--at least in the opinion of some critics. Absent here is Stewart's infallible common sense,and well known mental acuity, which always sets into motion his kinetic energy. He is no one's fool; witness, if you will, his provincial lawyer in "Anatomy of a Murder," a few years later, whose sterling common sense and undaunted intelligence sends a "city slicker" prosecutor packing. Steward is a sunny character, even if an occasional screen role make him vindictive, or a bit too loud. We tolerate him, because we like him. He gives confidence that, when he picks up a wrong, he rights it. We don't like him victimized--I don't see him that way.Simply put, here Stewart is not Stewart. He is befuddled, hesitant, susceptible to irrational passion unfitting his common sense persona, and, to top this, duped by a woman he blindly follows and believes, though her hokey story about cemeteries, a dead grandmother whom she resembles and wants to die for, and other such perilously thin stories should have given a man of his rational powers some pause. With the Rear Window Stewart still fresh in memory, I cannot abide a character astutely aware of neighborly misdoings (and murder), in that movie, now in this one being duped by a well disguised woman whose husband has told him a tall story about her past. Admittedly, Kim Novak, in her metamorphosis as a blond temptress is very alluring, but that is exactly what a seasoned detective like Scottie should be able to detect. I cannot stand seeing him becoming such a fool. Perhaps the coroner (Henry Jones) during the inquest is right in saying how neglectful of his duties he was; how his fear of heights became the cause of the death of a woman. I fault his going to the tower following her in the first place. Scottie is fooled once, and, as we will see a bit later, he is fooled twice.Again, Stewart's qualities as an American hero and Hitchcock regular are not in question.  But this persona of the straight-shooting, honest, passionate man, which works well in "black-and-white," right or wrong situations, does not quite fit the more complex, ambiguous character Stewart is playing here. For instance, this vertigo business: In the first scene of the movie, he is left hanging from a roof, while deft camera work (vertical shooting?) renders his psychological condition (trauma). There is nothing wrong with that--even a man of Stewart's down-to-earth image can be seen as an ex-detective, suffering from a mental malady, being loved by a woman he doesn't really want (Bel Geddes), and retired as a man of independent means. But to introduce a man/actor of healthy vital instincts as a sick man in the first scene of the movie seems to be playing against the actor's strong points. To be immobile (as in Rear Window) and have his leg in a cast is one thing; he is still mentally alert and even cheerful. But to be swooning in the arms of Bel Geddes (Midge) seems like a weakness too debilitating to be acceptable to society (as the coroner at the inquest later states) or to a discerning fan.  The trouble begins as soon as the strange request from his friend, Tom Helmore (Gavin Elster), is made and Ferguson embarks on a seemingly quixotic quest of tracking a lady of mysterious origins who roams about town visiting museums and mission chapels and jumping into the San Francisco Bay, bent on killing herself, while Ferguson tries to save her life and in the process falls in love. Here Stewart's, the actor's, emotions work against the grain. For one thing, the usually sharp/alert and quick to suspect (Rope, Rear Window) Stewart seems strangely obtuse here, falling victim to the machinations of a woman of whom he practically knows nothing except what he has been told by her "husband." Why doesn't he check to find out who Helmore's wife really is? If he is asked to follow a woman suspected of suicidal tendencies, why doesn't he prod into her past--not what pictures she stares at in a museum--but finding out what her birth and marriage certificates say, and what the photos on them prove, for instance? Here, why does the alert and lucid Stewart of Rope and Rear Window become the "sucker" of a con-lady just because his "dark" passions pull him toward her? That might seem an adequate excuse for anyone, for passions are supposed to becloud a man's (and a woman's) judgment, but what one objects to is Stewart's slavish attachment to a client in a situation where his detective instincts should have told him what course of action to follow. He remains clueless, not only as to her actual identity, but also as to the fact that she has actually fallen in love with him, not in her faked persona but as the real Judy camouflaged as Madeleine. What he does not see is that it is not the woman who pretends to be Madeleine who loves him but her real person, Judy. His confusion is not understood by either himself, or the viewer, also an unsuspecting victim of this deception.  Of course, in a mystery the viewer is supposed to be deceived, but somehow the two confusions interfere with each other, in view of what happens later. No wonder that in the emotional scenes--in the bedroom after the rescue, the disappearance, his reaction after he sees her again wearing a white coat--Stewart's reactions and feelings seem strained, as if the actor is incapable of dealing with their complexity. Stewart, the actor, is excellent when dealing with external forces--a callous system, a murderous opponent--but his range seems limited when the force he wrestles with is inside him. Here the actor needs to deal simultaneously with a mental malady (fear of heights), an assignment where he has to guess a great deal, and falling in love with the woman he is supposed to protect. An actor with an extraordinary range is needed (an Olivier, for instance?), and here Stewart's limitations show. In his previous movies he battled with external evil--murder, his child's abduction--but his inner world remained undisturbed. He handled those situations--always as an actor--easily, and successfully, though some degree of distress was involved. But here he strains to achieve believability, so he knocks about town, being manipulated, seeming magnetized, and a dupe to a duplicity that should have been detected.His problem is accelerated and intertwined with the problems of the characterization of Judy given by Ms. Novak in the film's second part. Here he himself (Stewart) seems much more comfortable with his role, for he now deals, almost exclusively, with only one problem, the identification of Judy. But the mystery is removed from the viewer, who right away knows, from Judy's letter, what the deception was. The problem though is not the progress of unraveling the mystery--Hitchcock is too much of a master to make any false steps here, but with the premise of the film itself: is it really possible for us, the viewers, to believe that a downtrodden, practically uneducated woman (from Kansas) could play the role of the aristocratic, polished, alluring, eloquently sexual Madeleine? Judy herself confesses in the letter we hear her read that Helmore, her partner in crime, had coached her well how to do this, but the viewer still remains unconvinced that the metamorphosis (and the one that follows back to Madeleine) is credible. The identification of the character of Judy is a poor device to end Vertigo. Stewart's compulsion here dissolves, once he notices the necklace with the ruby she is wearing, an article that the man had given the fake Madeleine as a gift before departing for abroad. She wears it either absently, or deliberately to force Ferguson to forget the dead woman and love her, the same, and always alive Judy. She does not count on his obsession not with an actual person, but a "dead" one, but the reconciliation is impossible and Ferguson, his detective instincts now in full alert, drives her to the scene of the crime, the tower where the crime can be re-enacted. Judy as a character is shown as a crude, if not infantile, common person, who seems an unlikely type for promotion into the delicate, unbalanced, but sophisticated and scheming Madeleine. If the plotline had been reversed and the Judy story had come first, and her connivance with Helmore in plain view, the development of suspense could have taken a different path, for the viewer could have been curious to know what could have happened next. This works in Rope, which moves along without a stumble, and more or less in Psycho, where cause and effect work to full advantage. Vertigo had difficulties being accepted by the public at first; but critics have resurrected it. It still has the master's touches: costumes by Edith Head, splendid photography, a suggestive musical score. What it lacks is a little pulse--to this viewer. This review ha so far generated five nos and one yes. I expect more of the former.

reviewText: I first saw this movie when I was six. It is interesting how certain visual images will strike someone so strongly, implant themselves in one's brain so that one never forgets them. At the age of six I registered neither the story nor the meaning, but for the next twelve years the general impact of the movie did not leave me. I remember the swirling of the credits, and the name Carlotta on a gravestone in a sunny, flowery churchyard; I remembered the mission tower and how Jimmy Stewart kept looking down as he climbed those stairs; I remembered how beautiful I thought Kim Novak was with that hair and all her snappy outfits; and I remembered Carlotta's necklace. All I could recall of the story was something about how the man thought the woman was dead and it ended up she wasn't but then got killed. I frequently made up stories in my head about a woman who supposedly died. Later her boyfriend would find her again and take her back to the place she was said to have died - and then she'd die for real. And when she died she would be wearing a beautiful black velvet dress.So when after twelve years I watched this movie again, I was glad to finally understand the story and see all those things I remembered and loved when I first watched it, only now they all made sense. I suppose my opinion of this movie would be this: Much as I love Hitchcock, this isn't the most wonderful movie ever made. Still, it IS very good, I enjoy it very much, and it is definitely not a waste of time, if you like intrigue and "weird" plots. It's interesting to watch the downward spiral of Scotty's obsession with Madeleine - like a maelstrom at sea, once he was pulled in, he could never escape, and it ended in destruction for him as well as "Madeleine".I've always thought of this film as being in two distinct parts: Act 1, Madeleine; and Act 2, Judy. The first half, Scotty pursues a woman who pretends to be possessed by an ancestress; in the second half, the woman who has pretended comes back to his life to possess him. Ultimately she destroys herself through allowing him in his obsession to make her what she should never have been. Kim Novak may not be the most dynamic actress - she is certainly no Grace Kelly or Ingrid Bergman. Still, she is a beautiful woman, and her dreamy acting in this film complements her role as Madeleine. She puts on a hard front for a little while as Judy, but as she gives in more and more to Scotty, Madeleine comes back. And that's how we want to see her - like Scotty, we want her to be Madeleine, even though we know no good can come of it.I also must put in a word for Barbara Bel Geddes who played Midge, Scotty's former fiancée. She is wonderful, quite funny and motherly, and I love both scenes in her apartment. The first when she is drawing the advertisement illustration for the brassiere designed after the cantilever bridge concept, and the second when she paints a self-portrait after the manner of the Carlotta portrait. One of the saddest moments in the movie is when she leaves the institution where Scotty has been put - walking alone down the dark hall, leaving Scotty, and leaving us. Her heart is breaking. We do not see her again.I highly recommend this movie.

reviewText: This happens to be my favorite Hitchcock film.The DVD is great.  There are interviews and extras galore!This is considered Hitchcock's most personal film. Almost simultaneously, an old friend calls upon him to follow the Mrs.  Apparently she slips into trances that take her back to another time (and into insanity!).  But complications arise as Scotty realizes his attraction to her has little to do with the job ...This is a movie I watch over and over again.  The funny thing is, I have talked to many others who have the same obsessive reaction to it as well.Give it one viewing, and you will be hooked.

reviewText: Echoes of VERTIGO reverberate through the films of David Lynch, Terry Gilliam, and Brian De Palma.  In fact, the film's hallucinatory images, Wagnerian musical score, and famous "zoom-pullback" photography have become a part of our collective film psyches.  And no wonder: the film is one of the American cinema's most haunting.  James Stewart's performance is a classic, one of our great actors exploring his dark side fearlessly and passionately.  His final ascent up the bell tower with Kim Novak (who eerily handles the peculiar demands of her role) is terrifying and unforgettable.  This man's descent into obsession has been so vividly rendered that we almost can't bear to see what happens next.  What is most astonishing about VERTIGO is how beautiful it is.  Hitchcock photographs San Francisco in vivid color and seemingly through a series of filters which lend it a dreamy, surrealistic quality.  It is rare to find a film that works on you long after the lights have gone up, but VERTIGO's potent mix of erotic obsession, fetishism, and anxiety will stay with you for years to come.  Is it any wonder that its images keep showing up in our films?

reviewText: With fifty feature-length films to his credit, Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) churned out nearly a film a year for the better part of his adult life. 2008 marks the 50th anniversary of Vertigo, a film of dark dreams, obsession of a type that is more like possession, madness, fear, love and guilt. And no small amount of mystery and intrigue until the final minutes. Set in San Francisco, Jimmy Stewart stars as Scotty, a detective who had to retire from the police force because of a traumatic experience with heights. We know what his vertigo begot in the first minutes of the film, but not in the very last scene. Scotty does his college friend Gavin a favor, which is to tail his wife Madeleine who has been "possessed" by the long-dead Carlotta Valdes. That kindness turns out to be a distinctly bad idea. The scenery, the ominous musical score, the now quaint roles of gender and justice, and Hitchcock's genius for mining the depths of the human psyche all make Vertigo well worth watching fifty years on.

reviewText: This review is for the 2003 Collector's Edition Universal Studios DVD.The basic storyline of this film involves police detective named John "Scottie" Ferguson (Jimmy Stewart) who retires due to his fear of heights caused by a medical condition known as vertigo.  Shortly after retiring, Scottie is hired by an old college acquaintance to work as a private detective to follow his wife.  The reason for following this woman (played by Kim Novak) is she appears to be possessed by a dead woman and may be suicidal.  Scottie eventually becomes romantically involved with this woman, but a tragic event occurs and then remainder of the movie reveals a surprising revelation pertaining to this devastating incident.There are many ingredients to a great movie: stunning cinematography, superb acting, effective directing, and an engaging screenplay.  The problem with this film is that the first three ingredients were present, but the screenplay was just very ordinary at best.  The first problem is that the Jimmy Stewart/Kim Novak relationship took way too long to develop.  Very little happens for the first 60 minutes of the film.  The second problem is that a clever crime has been committed, but the only way the audience knows this is by the one of the characters basically divulging it directly to the viewers in an uncreative way.  Once that occurs, the element of suspense is minimized and now it becomes more of an exercise in curiosity of a morbid relationship.But in spite of these problems, the visual appearance of the story is a work of art in itself.  The movie was filmed in San Francisco and other scenic parts of Northern California with a gorgeous color widescreen presentation.  The nostalgic aura of seeing that city and surrounding county in rich, lush color before it became overpopulated and overdeveloped is a treat in itself.  There are also numerous special effects used which were clearly revolutionary for its time.  The acting and the directing are also top notch, and the story effectively uses less dialogue and more visual effects to tell the story.  Overall, I still give this movie a marginally strong recommendation mainly due to the great merits of the cinematography.As for the DVD, the color widescreen presentation is relatively sharp and very colorful for a film this old.  From the bonus material we learn that this movie was restored and claims that it took two full years to meticulously bring back this film to its original state (although it appears that the sound and music may not be completely original).  However, the restoration still did not remove every single visual flaw, which was disappointing.  Some stray artifacts or tiny specs of film deterioration were easily noticed in the opening credits and a bit less for the remainder of the movie.  There are several wonderful bonus features including the making of the movie Vertigo with many interviews with people involved with the production and an interesting segment regarding the restoration of the film.Movie: B+DVD Quality: A-
summary: A visual masterpiece that is slightly blemished by a problematic screenplay

reviewText: Vertigo is an amazing, incredibly absorbing motion picture.  This is vintage Hitchcock--complex, disturbing, and brilliantly shot.  San Francisco has never looked more beautiful than it does in this movie, which features backdrops of the Golden Gate Bridge, a forest of giant sequoias, and other local landmarks.  Jimmy Stewart, one of my personal favorites, delivers a dead-on performance, and Kim Novak is wonderful in her dual role (even though I kept wishing Grace Kelly were playing the role).  Even some of the bit actors are stars in their own right--"Grandma Walton" plays a hotel manager and "Milburn Drysdale" from The Beverly Hillbillies plays a doctor.  In a more important (and somewhat confusing) role, Barbara Bel Geddes (Miss Ellie from TV's Dallas) plays Scottie Ferguson's (Stewart's) long-time friend.  The music is a perfect fit with the cascading emotions of the story, as Hitchcock understood just how important the musical score is to the overall presentation.  The sense of vertigo is conveyed rather well by the camera action, and the psychedelic dream-like sequence was original and intriguingly uncanny.  I cannot imagine why this film was not a ringing success with critics and fans alike when it was initially released because it is a model of incredible filmmaking.I hesitate to even mention the plot because it is incredibly complex and should be experienced by the first-time viewer with no preconceptions and no prior knowledge of the twists and turns involved.  It is a pleasure to watch a movie in which the viewer simply must participate on an intellectual level to grasp the evolution of the plot.  I believe the plot is hard to figure out, which is a wonderful thing.  My own initial suspicions were quite wrong, I am pleased to say, although I was a little disappointed that the character who earned my suspicions was sort of forgotten in the final stages of the action.This movie is a masterpiece.  It works on all levels, and while some may feel the first half of the film develops a little slowly, there is plenty of action and revelation to be found in the last half.  It is a little over two hours long, so you should be sure to set aside enough time to watch the movie without any interruptions or breaks.  And for goodness' sake, do not let anyone tell you what happens before you watch it.

reviewText: Just take everyone's word on this one: go out and buy yourself a copy of VERTIGO.  That's right.  You can walk right by the rental store and purchase it for yourself.  You'll thank me.  VERTIGO is one of those films that I can watch many times (even in a relatively short time span) and not get tired of it.  There is just something about it that keeps me coming back.  Maybe it is the way the storyline manages to "hook" you, dragging you further and further into the main character's obsession.  Perhaps it is the beautiful camera work, the glorious colors, or the very haunting soundtrack.  This transfer is excellent-much better than the older version I can remember watching as a kid.  Or perhaps it is the way that Hitchcock manages to transform a rather simple murder-mystery into something that stabs a knife into all of our hearts.  Whatever it is, VERTIGO has it in spades.James Stewart and Kim Novak are superb in this film.  In fact, both of their performances seem effortless.  I kept getting the feeling while watching this film that I wasn't watching a movie.  It seems too real, too penetrating for cinema.  It's like we've been invited along for a two hour ride inside of Hitchcock & Stewart's mind, inside the mind of a man possessed by a dream.  Perhaps what is so engaging about the plot is the fact that we can all relate to such obsession.  It is painful to watch in the same way that it is painful to watch loved ones decline (or it is to watch ourselves descend into madness).As I said before: you have to see this film.  It's as simple as that.  Period.
summary: Do Yourself a Favor: Just Buy It.

reviewText: Alfred Hitchcock's VERTIGO is one of the 50 best movies ever made. I personally know one person who watches it every two months and still discovers in this movie some food for his mind. It's true that VERTIGO has been analyzed in numerous books after the brilliant articles in "The Cahiers du Cinéma" written by the future heroes of the Nouvelle Vague : Claude Chabrol, Jean-Luc Godard and Franois Truffaut. VERTIGO is one of this movies which directly speaks to your heart if you're a cinephile, like Peter Bogdanovich's THE LAST PICTURE SHOW or John Ford's THE SEARCHERS.Why does this particular movie speak to me more than the others ? For a simple reason, James Stewart is the mirror through which every cinephile can recognize himself. During long moments, Alfred Hitchcock films James Stewart in his car following Kim Novak ; no words are spoken, there is only Bernard Hermann's musical score and the face of James Stewart. At this moment, you are staring with intensity at a man who stares with intensity at a beautiful woman you too would like to stare at with intensity. Then, you enter the movie lover's vertigo, you become James Stewart.No need to say that VERTIGO was the first DVD I've bought and should have a place, in my opinion, in any honest man's library (in the XVIIIth century meaning of the word). English, spanish and french subtitles, a commentary, trailers, the second ending and other goodies.A DVD which is already in your library.

reviewText: Is there anything left to say about 'Vertigo'?  How would you describe it to someone who had never seen it: a Martian, say?  You couldn't claim it was the greatest film ever made, the last Modernist film, the ultimate film about watching films: s/he wouldn't know what you were talking about.You could say it was a detective film, about an investigator who loses his modus operandi, his mind.  you could say it was a dream, the story of a man who sleepwalks through a non-existent illusory world, created by Gavin Elster, alias Alfred Hitchcock.  You could use it to reveal the character of Men, their boundless, self-deluding, myth-making capacity for romance, and murderous, self-centred, emotional brutalism.  You could call it a labyrinth in which the different paths are made of Time, and the walls created by Colour, Music, Paintings, Stories, San Francisco, Religion.  You could tell them that Bernard Herrmann's music will haunt them forever, score their own obsessive memories.  You could even proffer it as a prime example of religious film-making, of one man's damnation as he strives for redemption.whatever you do, you'd better advise them not to watch it at all, because it would convince them that they were an inferior species, and that one portly Englishman, nearly half a century ago, found the key to the Truth, and ran away with it.  We've been chasing him through 'Vertigo' ever since.  Delirious.

Go figure.

reviewText: Vertigo would probably not make my list of the top five Hitchcock movies, but not because it is not five stars.  It is every bit of that and then some.  It's just that I like some others a little more.  This may be Sir Alfred's most complex and deep movie ever.  Unlike North by Northwest, which came out the year after Vertigo and was very much a fast paced action film without a lot of thinking involved, Vertigo takes place almost exclusively in the characters' minds.  Until you realize that, the movie can seem slow and dull.  Once you see how Jimmy Stewart is manipulated, you understand the horror of Vertigo.Stewart plays Scottie, a former detective who had to quit because he lost a partner in an unfortunate fall from a roof.  Scottie developed a fear of heights from this accident and has vertigo when he climbs even a little ladder.  This renders him almost useless in the field of detective work.A former friend named Gavin, knowing Scottie is out of work, hires him to trail his wife (Kim Novak).  Gavin thinks his wife is crazy, that she believes she is someone who died many years ago.  Scottie reluctantly takes the job and begins following the woman to report to Gavin how she spends her afternoons.  It is strange what she does.What I have done is just set the physical scene.  But believe me, the real story is ahead.  There is tragedy in the movie, along with a complete switch of characters.  Eventually the watcher learns what has happened to the characters in the movie, but the way Stewart is cruelly manipulated throughout is tragic.  I would rather not give away what is really going on.  I would only encourage you to give the film at least two viewings to try to catch the whole storyThis has been called Hitchcock's most personal film.  It is certainly the most emotional of his work, showing the heartbreak that comes with true love being ripped away in an incredibly cruel manner.  It took me several viewings to really grasp what this movie was about.  I have loved it since.By the way, the top 5 Hitchcock movies in my opinion:1) Notorious2) North by Northwest3) Psycho4) Rear Window5) Strangers on a Train

reviewText: Vertigo is considered one of the greatest films ever made and celebrated as Hitchcock's masterpiece.  Perhaps it is.  But I found myself bored as I watched it even though I had to admire the artistic intent.  There are so many holes in the film it could qualify as cheesy.  However, try telling that to those who love it.  I think they love it as much for its flaws as for its perfections.Perfections: the feel of the San Francisco Bay area, the sense of historical California, the great beauty of the ocean framed by Monterey cypresses, the redwoods, the Golden Gate Bridge as seen from below and off to the side, the Bautista Mission, the fifties interior decor, Madeleine's costumes, the angle of Scottie's fedora, the acting by the three stars, James Stewart, Kim Novak, and Barbara Bel Geddes.  The musical score by Bernard Herrmann is also celebrated, but I found it a bit overbearing at times, and of course Hitchcock loved using music to direct our sensitivities, and one can tire of that.Flaws:Scottie hanging from the drainpipe railing, watching the cop trying to save him fly over to land several stories down, dead.  What is not explained is how the cop was expected to pull him up with nothing to hold onto or how Scottie managed to survive.  Apparently he fell but only broke his back because in the next scene he is in surgical corset unable to scratch certain itches.The ersatz psychology.  It was the fifties and psychoanalytic psychology was all the rage.  One of the bestsellers of the day was The Fifty-Minute Hour: A Collection of True Psychoanalytic Tales by Robert Lindner in which a shrink relates tales told by his patients.  Hitchcock loved this sort of thing (cf., Spellbound (1945) with Gregory Peck and Ingrid Bergman).  Audiences also loved it.  But the psychology is strictly bananas.Driving on the wrong side of the road (about which Hitchcock is reported to have said when it was pointed out to him, "You drive your way.  I'll drive mine.")The plot.  Oh, the plot.  Never but never has there been a more elaborate and unlikely murder-your-rich-wife scheme.  Judy Barton is hired, persuaded or, gee, maybe hypnotized into playing Gavin Elster's wife who is to commit suicide by jumping off the bell tower at the mission.  First Gavin (Tom Helmore) has to establish that she's crazy and suicidal.  This is done by having her drive dreamily around the Frisco Bay area looking for the haunts of her great grandmother who committed suicide.  The key is to get Scottie to believe it so he can testify that she was suicidal.  For this to work, (1) Madeleine has to fool a police detective--one might say mesmerize him, which she does, (2) Get him to the bell tower at the right time where he is afraid to go to the top--that works, but you have to buy the psychology, (3) Time it so that Madeleine appears to jump off, but in reality you throw the dead body of your wife off after having broken her neck (body kept warm perhaps in your car with the heater on?), (4) Hide with Madeleine at the top of the tower until the coast is clear (whenever that might be).Although Kim Novak's performance is interesting it is unlikely that she could fool ex-detective Scottie into believing she was somebody else.  When she reappears as Judy Barton in the brown hair and the different makeup, it really makes the audience do a double take before realizing that she and Madeleine are the same.  But Scottie's take seems to be that she (and some other women at first glance) look like Madeleine--after all, he just got out of the nut house.  It is only when he sees the necklace that he comes to his senses.Another thing afficionados love about this movie is the way Hitchcock was able to subtly strip his stars of their glamour and make them look more or less human.  James Stewart never played a part anything like this before.  All the funny faces he has to make, perplexed while driving, terrified on the way up the bell tower, insane and terrified in the dream sequence, etc.  It is said that Hitchcock blamed the lack of popular success of this movie (when it was belatedly released, not now) on Stewart looking too old, and therefore Hitchcock never worked with him again.  But I think Stewart, after seeing the way he looked in this movie--so unheroic, so lost as a real human being--decided he was never going to let Hitchcock do THAT to him again, and that's probably why they never worked together again.Kim Novak's curvy body and flopping you-know-whats are revealed in outfits that Grace Kelly would never wear.  And poor Barbara Bel Geddes with those most unattractive glasses!  How she pines for Scottie.  One of the best scenes occurs when she shows Scottie her self portrait as the mysterious Carlotta with the glasses on (!) followed by her "Stupid, stupid, stupid!" self-flagellation after Scottie, who was offended at the grotesque sight, walks out.But why is Scottie always hanging out at her place?  And how they talk the plot in the beginning so that we might know that they were once a couple!  But Hitchcock never worried about anything but the effect his movie might have on the audience.  Improbilities, clumsy plot devices, etc., were secondary.  And you know what, he was right, as P.T. Barnum was right.  Hitchcock never overestimated the sophistication of his audience and that was one of his strengths.  The audience just wants to be entertained, to be diverted, to live the fantasy for a while.Somebody said that the real entertainment in watching this movie is in watching it again after you know the story.  I think they're right.  It's definitely a film buff's movie.

reviewText: Alfred Hitchcock's "Vertigo" is one of those rare pieces of cinematic art: every time you watch it, you see something in it you failed to notice before.  Nothing in the movie, despite its langourous pacing, is haphazard or accidental.  Consider Hitchcock's use of color and the way he associates it with his characters.Throughout the first half of the movie, Jimmy Stewart's character of Scotty Ferguson wears a brown suit with a red print or striped tie almost exclusively.  There are exceptions, but Hitchcock clearly wants to connect Scotty with the color brown.  Brown is the color of the earth, but it is the barren earth, which has not been planted.  It is awaiting life, as is the character of Scotty, retiring from the police force, still a bachelor.When Scotty agrees to help his college friend Gavin Elster by trailing his wife Madelaine, the first place Scotty sees Madelaine is in the red silk wallpapered rooms of Ernie's in San Francisco.  The symbolism of seeing the stunning Kim Novak walking through a background of red, with its connotations of passion and sexuality couldn't be more obvious.  Madelaine's appearance is made all the more stunning by her wearing a black velvet dress with a black silk shawl with a striking green border.  Black, of course, is the color of death, despair and impending doom, while green symbolizes new life, fertility and hope.  The significance of the intermingling of these contradictory emotional states proceed and develop throughout the picture.  When Scotty begins to trail Madelaine, she drives around the city in a green Jaguar.  After Scotty rescues Madelaine by pulling her out of the bay, we get one of the few scenes in the first half of the picture where Scotty wears something other than the brown suit.  When Madelaine awakes in Scotty's apartment, he is wearing a white shirt, black slacks and a green sweater.  The influence of Madelaine's character on that of Scotty is made plain by the use of color.  What's going on beneath the surface is made all the more clear by the fact that she emerges from Scotty's bedroom wearing his red silk bathrobe.Consider the brown suit for a moment.  The persistent use of brown represents an obsessive-compulsive disorder.  It signifies that something terrible is about to happen to this character, and is psychologically associated with depression and suicidal tendencies.  If "Vertigo" is about anything, it is about Scotty's compulsive need to possess the object of his obsession: Madelaine.Madelaine combines the color white with her blacks and greens.  White, of course, is the color of purity, but it is also the color of truth and complexity.  When Madelaine appears on Scotty's doorstep emerging from her green Jaguar in a combination of black and white, the complex interplay of the color symbols reflect the deepening complexities of the plot, as well as Madelaine's relationship with Scotty.  When she next appears at Scotty's doorstep, she is wearing the famous gray suit, which symbolizes that nothing is clear anymore, and everything is compromised.At the coroner's inquest, we see Scotty for the first time in a blue suit, with its overtones of sincerity, intense personal issues and the need for change.  This is slighty offset by his wearing a green and gray striped tie.  When Scotty has his nervous breakdown and Midge comes to visit him in the hospital, he is again wearing a white shirt, black slacks and a blue sweater.After his emergence from the hospital, Scotty is again seen in a blue suit, representing his unresolved personal female issues, and then a gray suit, representing his confused eros and thanatos desires.  It is no accident, however, that when he first spots Judy, Madelaine's doppleganger, that he is back to wearing his familiar brown suit, and she appears wearing a green blouse with white polka dots and a green skirt.  When Judy and Scotty go out on their first dates, she wears a lilac colored dress.  Purple is the color of the pennitent, who seek forgiveness.  It is also associated with new beginnings (Advent and Lent), and lilacs bloom in the spring.  But lilac is a shade of purple mixed with the overtones of truth and the complexities of white.  Before her date with Scotty, Judy writes him a confessional letter, but discards it.  Her lilac dress signifies her desire for a new beginning, but also her subliminal sexual feelings for Scotty (red), along with her own unresolved issues (blue)and the complexity of the truth of her situation (white).  Scotty wears his strong, sincere blue suit, showing that his issues are still unresolved.Things only get worse as Scotty makes Judy over in the image of Madelaine.  When Judy comes back to her apartment wearing Madelaine's gray suit, her hair bleached blonde like Madelaine's, and Scotty has her pin her hair up the way Madelaine did, she emerges from a backlit nimbus of green light from the neon sign outside her window.  The transformation is now complete.  Scotty now possesses the object of his obsession, but as Neitzsche observed: "In the end, we love our desires, not the object of our desires," and the end of Judy's and Scotty's dreams is very near at hand."Vertigo" is perhaps Hitchcock's greatest masterpiece.  Everything is chosen with meticulous care, and everything serves both the development of the story and Hitchcock's themes of dreams, obsession and possession.
summary: The Use of Color Symbolism in Hitchcock's "Vertigo"

reviewText: James Stewart can do no wrong in my eyes, and probably in the eyes of the vast majority of the movie-going public. It is obvious why he was a favourite of Alfred Hitchcock's. Here he shows not only his usual charm, but also a slightly sinister side, evidence of his great talents as an actor and not just a star. The plot is interesting, and best enjoyed if you don't try to guess ahead. The restored version shows the beautiful colour of the original and particularly the fine costume design. The sound restoration is also worthy of mention. It is handled sensitively by re-creating the sound effects in stereo and adding a clean copy of the Bernard Hermann score to the best versions of the dialogue the restorers could find. It might lack authenticity but it does make the film more enjoyable than some of the worn-out prints we had been used to, which really did not do the film justice.

reviewText: VERTIGO remains one of the most thought-provoking films I have ever seen.  I still remember my first taste of this film (at least thirteen years ago!).  It's safe to say (without exaggeration) that it changed my life and how I view cinematography.  Yes, I know that is a tall statement to make about this movie, but it's well-merited.  Why?  For starters, Alfred Hitchcock's depiction of the medical condition of vertigo (extreme dizziness onset by perceived or actual drops in height--example:  standing at the top of a tall staircase and glancing down at the ground floor from where you stand) feels like, both, a deep acid trip (complete with spinning imagery and disorientation), as well as a really extreme look at the effect of this condition on Scotty (James Stewart), a retired policeman, hired by an old friend to follow his beautiful wife (Kim Novak) who believes is possessed by the dead soul of a mad woman.  Of course, this woman also has a penchant for ascending to great heights and attempting to jump off of them.  This only adds another twist to Scotty's pursuit of the woman.Alfred Hitchcock always had a flair for bringing the ironic, gothic and darkly comedic all to the foreground, in his films.  Cinematography was one way he achieved (and manipulated) these emotions in the stories he wove so eloquently, on screeen.  VERTIGO is no exception.  What's more, Kim Novak is a very compelling and beautiful actress who stepped out of her more "cheesecake" roles to play the role of Madeleine, a very deeply disturbed (and perhaps, psychologically pursued?) woman with a secret.  What's more, I love James Stewart, here.  His relationship with Madeleine is conflicted and borders on pseudo-erotic.  Of course, I won't divulge more plot details here.  I just figured dropping that clue would tease and tantalize you enough to want to see this great film for yourself.  I am so glad that it was given the kudos it deserved, with a re-released DVD addition.  Great news!!!

reviewText: Now Vertigo has surpassed Citizen Kane in the Sight and Sound poll as the number one best film of all time, but, to my way of thinking, the entire story centers around the singular triumphant moment where Scottie has finally managed to recreate Judy in the image of the lost Madeleine. Coming as it does, after an untold period of Scottie wandering through a dark night of the soul, it is a moment of great release, a kind of healing and liberation.  And of course this moment of extreme wish fulfillment is followed in the next scene, by his searing discovery of the broach that had been worn by 'Carlotta'. Exhibit 'A' for the prosecution. This is clearly a devastating disillusionment for Scottie, and Jame Stewart plays it perfectly. This is the proverbial moment of truth, in which he finally understands that all his obsession and suffering was the product of a delusion, imposed upon him by the cunning of others. And herein lies the essential psychological truth of the pain of emotional trauma, the grief of loss. This is a feeling that is played with in all it's delicious permutations by Bernard Herrmann in his brilliant score. Sometimes--enlightenment is not a pretty thing.Analyzed rationally, the story beggar's belief. Easy to understand how a traumatic brush with death could produce a fear of heights. That a friend should devise a complex murder plot to off his wife, built entirely around that phobia, and enlist a young woman from Kansas to run a complex scam on the retired cop is more than most grown ups are able to believe. In spite of the improbability of this scheme, there are so many genuinely poignant and haunting moments in the film, and something very real about the nature of the pain of romantic obsession is conveyed. Anyone who has ever succumbed to an unrequited love affair, or lost a loved one, knows these feelings, and therein lies the truth of the film. The scene in Muir Woods where Madeleine points to the ancient cut tree rings--who cannot relate to that sense of smallness adrift in the vastness of time. The scenes where Scottie keeps trying to dress Judy, and coif her hair, is reminiscent of  the artist striving to actualize an aesthetic vision, and it suggests a commonality of both types of obsession, and infatuation, erotic, and artistic. If the film is seen as a kind of nightmare that explores the illusions that frequently underlie our infatuations, it works.On the other hand--as a straight murder mystery, it is hard to swallow. This may be the reason for the mixed critical reviews when it first came out. However, when I first saw it, at the age of 9, it was truly mind blowing. But what does a 9 year old know about the reality of adult emotions. Hitchcock claimed it was a mistake to cast the 50 year old Stewart with 25 year old Kim Novak--however, that seems like a feeble attempt to evade the problems that are fundamental to the story itself. If he had cast William Holden instead, would it really have made that much of a difference?So, what about this dark night of the soul business? Scottie blames himself for being unable to master his vertigo and save Madeleine from committing suicide. And the viewer, like Scottie, can understand his sense of guilt, inadequacy and despair. He was tried in the balance, and found wanting. The public hearing is brutal. His suffering is real, his despair and psychological torment unrelenting--and yet, in that single instant when his detective's mind grasps the significance of the broach, when all his efforts at recreating the vision of the woman he thought he'd lost have borne fruit -- he realized that everything he knew was wrong. He'd been a sap. He'd been completely hoodwinked. He'd been duped into covering up and concealing a murder--a murder he had never even suspected, of a woman he didn't even know. It was all an illusion. It had no reality. There was no substance. There was no 'there' there. So,what about the origins, the source of his unrelenting nightmare phase? What is Hitchcock trying to tell us about the nature of our own psychology? Of our own vulnerability? What is he trying to tell us about the nature of his OWN obsessions, his OWN torments? Again, Hitchcock goes a very long way to make a point, but in the process he gets to the kernel of the truth of our psychology, and the extent to which  our worlds are only sand castles in the air, and each of us is under the spell of one powerful illusion after another. As Prospero remarked in The Tempest: "We are such stuff As dreams are made on; and our little life Is rounded with a sleep."Anyway, these top ten lists are annoying. Half the films on that list are pretty much un-watchable, today, IMHO. And some of my favorite films didn't even make it. Fie on all top ten lists.
summary: I Left My Heart in San Francisco

reviewText: Hitchcock's "Vertigo" (1958) is about a San Francisco detective, John "Scottie" Ferguson (James Stewart) who has acrophobia (vertigo). He is hired as a private detective, after having retired from police work, by Gavin Elster (Tom Helmore), in order to follow his delusional wife, Madeleine Elster (Kim Novak). Though after a time, it is Scottie who is apparently losing his mind. There is a haunting scene at Muir Woods National Monument, among the coastal redwoods, where Madelaine has slipped away from Scottie. The forest acts here like a metaphor for his decent into a labyrinth of confusion.When Madeleine gets ahead of him at the Mission at San Juan Bautista he realizes his mistake, and chases her up the tower, but he is too late to help as his vertigo prevents him from catching up to her, and he sees her fall from the roof top. Scottie's guilt pesters him from this point on, and he begins to see Madeleine whenever he sees a blond. This is Scottie's hell on earth as his obsession takes over and he circles back to the same moment, again and again. He seems to be losing his mind, and is eventually confined temporarily to a sanitarium. Once Scottie is out of the sanitarium he eventually finds a girl who looks a lot like Madeleine. We wonder if he has lost his mind, and is only seeing what he wants to see.The vertigo that Scottie experiences, which is repeated in various circular motifs throughout the film, from spiral stairways, to the circular form of Madeleine's hair style, seems to be pointing Scottie down a vortex of confusion, as his life gets ever more lost in a madness that he can't seem to control. Hitchcock employs many ingenious devices to convey Scottie's plunge into insanity, from dream sequences, to scenes that spiral about him. In one brilliant scene Scottie and Judy are embracing in a room that spirals about them to reveal them now in a horse stall, and then again in the room, with the background turning to a brilliant, hypnotic blue. It is scenes like this, and the hypnotic pacing, as the film progressively speeds up, that reveal this movie to be the masterpiece that it is. In the last half of the movie we see why Hitchcock is the master of suspense. The film builds to a feverish pitch as Scottie's passion, and obsession, seem to be overriding his reason.As a footnote, this film has been remastered. The original film was badly faded, and has been greatly improved through modern techniques. In October 1996, the restored "Vertigo" premiered for the first time in DTS, and 70mm, which is a format similar in frame size to the VistaVision system that the film was originally shot in. The one caveat though is that Foley's sound effects were totally re-recorded. Harris and Katz sometimes also added extra sounds, and it is said that the new mix puts too much emphasis on the film score by Bernard Hermann over the sound effects. For one wanting to hear the original mono track it is available as an option in the 2005 Hitchcock Masterpiece Collection DVD set.

reviewText: This legendary 1958 masterwork from Alfred Hitchcock plays like grand Baroque opera full of exaggerated character motivations and preposterous plot turns, yet it is one of the most consistently involving of his impressive canon of films perhaps because he takes an unsavory subject, sexual obsession, and shapes around it a remarkably perceptive character-driven mystery thriller. Co-written with intricacy by Alec Coppel and Samuel A. Taylor, the tightly drawn story focuses on John "Scottie" Ferguson, a plainclothes detective who quits the police force after his partner dies during a rooftop chase where Ferguson is debilitated by a severe case of acrophobia. An old college acquaintance, now a shipping tycoon, convinces the now-retired Ferguson to follow his disturbed, potentially suicidal wife Madeleine, and thus begins Ferguson's first obsession.The film twists and turns until her apparent death from a fall from the San Juan Batista mission church steeple. This is where Hitchcock does something quite audacious. Suffering from this unexpected tragedy, the hero of the movie becomes a darker character we are suddenly not sure about. By fate back in San Francisco, Ferguson meets a shopgirl named Judy who bears enough of a physical resemblance to Madeleine for him to stalk her and force her to change her appearance to look like his lost love. At first, it feels rather necrophilic if not downright deranged for Ferguson to act on his obsession of a dead woman, but regardless, a final twist makes the love between Ferguson and Judy impossible to endure. Hitchcock lends a deepening sense of emotionalism to the maddening but addictive spirals of the plot which ultimately makes the film's title even more resonant than the medical condition Ferguson has.Casting is crucial to making the storyline relevant to a viewer much less credible. In a nice change-of-pace, James Stewart makes Ferguson's obsession palpable, and his everyman demeanor takes on a convincing sinister edge, even though his natural affability sneaks through effectively as a counterbalance. In what remains a most underrated performance, Kim Novak manages to play her dual roles with a surprising lack of affectation, from the cool mystique of Madeleine to the desperate eagerness of Judy. Hitchcock uses Novak's natural detachment as an actress to the movie's advantage, as I doubt the more versatile Grace Kelly could have played at least the Judy part as well. Barbara Bel Geddes has precious few scenes in the relatively thankless role of Midge, Ferguson's sometime girlfriend. The San Francisco locations are used to great advantage - the Palace of Fine Arts, the Palace of the Legion of Honor, Fort Point, the now-defunct Ernie's restaurant, the Podesta Baldocchi flower shop, the cemetery at Mission Dolores -  all shot in lustrous detail by Robert Burks. Bernard Herrmann contributes one of his great scores to complement the pacing and atmosphere of the mystery and suspense.The DVD has the splendid 1996 restoration which captures all the visual and aural splendor of the film. It also includes an alternative commentary track that features Novak, restorers Robert Harris and James Katz, Hitchcock's daughter Patricia and most interestingly, associate producer Herbert Coleman who is full of anecdotes. Harris and Katz figure prominently in an interesting 1997 half-hour documentary on the original production and restoration process. There have been many knock-offs - including Brian DePalma's derivative 1976 "Obsession", Kenneth Branagh's blackly humorous 1991 "Dead Again" and most recently, Jun Ichikawa's coldly antiseptic 2005 "Tony Takitani" - but this is most definitely the one to experience.
summary: Obsession as Grand Melodrama in Hitchcock's Most Hypnotic Work

reviewText: The story itself has some holes, as do the characters. For instance, we find out early on that Scottie Ferguson has been trained as an attorney, yet he decides to become a street cop instead (???)--not too many attorneys become cops, so more insight into his career choice would be helpful in making this character credible. Also, where does Scottie--a retired street cop--get enough money to retire from his job, live in a luxurious San Francisco apartment, live his leisurely lifestyle.. all while having his "kept woman" Judy living in the lap of luxury?And am I the only one who gets the heebie-jeebies over the pairing of Kim Novak with Jimmy Stewart, who is 25-30 years her senior--looking every bit of his age? He looks old enough to be her father, maybe grandfather. And what's with that scene where "Madeline" regains consciousness and finds herself naked in Scottie's bed? Later in the scene, we find Madeline's clothes are hanging to dry in the next room, which means that Scottie must have stripped her naked while she was unconcious.. again, am I the only one who finds this creepy?The scenes where Scottie is shadowing Madeline were probably intended to be ominous and mysterious; instead, I found them amusing, because he does essentially nothing to conceal himself from "Madeline". However, this isn't as amusing as the phony way "Madeline" pines over Carlotta in front of Scottie. And if Scottie is such a hot-dog sleuth, you'd think he would have come across a picture of the real Madeline and figure things out long before he did (being the prominent woman Madeline was, you'd have thought her pictures would be all over the news after her death).This film is important in that we can see how it has inspired contemporary dramatic thrillers, especially the works of Brian De Palma. So it's good to watch as a sort of film history artifact. But it probably won't do much for those who are used to contemporary dramatic horror films and are simply looking to be entertained. As with many other films with a Bernard Hermann musical score, it is his music that contributes most to the film's eerie, suspenseful ambiance.
summary: Once a cutting-edge dramatic thriller.. but now seems over-rated

reviewText: The first time I saw this movie, I didn't actually see it. I heard it. It was playing so late at night, I was dozing on my bed when it finally came on the TV (which tended to be on, much of the time, in my bedroom). The music roused me from deeper sleep, and managed to keep me in an in-between state for the entire movie. Occasionally I would pry one eye open and see Jimmy Stewart and Kim Novak, talking, running, kissing. I knew some heavy-duty stuff was going on. And even though I didn't hear the dialog, the music told me everything I needed to know about the movie and its themes of love, obsession, deception, and ultimate loss.This was the most grown-up movie I had encountered up to that point. It's so grown-up, I'm not sure you can truly comprehend it if you're under 40. But that's okay - the music is a road map. If you've heard it, you'll never forget it. It will tell you exactly how Jimmy Stewart's character was feeling. You'll be swimming in deep water. And that's an experience everyone should have at least once.

reviewText: I have just read the last 20 or so reviews, and I am gratified to see that others besides myself found this film to have a deep impact, to be profoundly moving, and to be their favorite movie. This is a dark, complex,  very deep, but exhilirating and--yes--dizzying movie.  My parents took me  to see it when I was all of 6 years old!  At that time, I did not  understand the very end of the film, but nonetheless the fascinating  aspects of it--the musical score, the twists in the plot, the nightmare  sequence, the heartbreak, the rich colors, the tautness of Judy's  sweater--stuck with me for decades.  When I was able to see it again, some  25 years later, I realized that this is my personal favorite movie of all  time, which means that I think it is Hitchcock's best movie--and that is  high praise indeed.  This movie demands your full attention, similar to the  attention demanded by a symphony, but you will be very richly rewarded, and  perhaps your perceptions of life and love will be changed forever.

reviewText: Many believe that this was greatest work of a master renowned for the outstanding direction of suspense thrillers.  Alfred Hitchcock creates a vortex of emotion and deception in this classic film about obsession.There are so many complex themes to this story that it requires several viewings to appreciate.  It metamorphoses numerous times, shifting from a detective story, to a love story, to a murder mystery, and finally to neurotic obsession.  It is a deep character study of flawed characters.  Some are not what they appear to be and others change before our eyes.Hitchcock's direction is superb, not only from the standpoint of assembling the story, but from a technical perspective as well.  The photography, lighting and perspectives are brilliantly done and the locations wonderfully selected, especially the shots at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Hitchcock also brings forth outstanding performances from Kim Novak and James Stewart.  Stewart generally played admirable and heroic characters in his career, so the deeply flawed John Ferguson was a clear departure for him.  This is probably his best and most gut wrenching performance. I don't think it would have been possible without Hitchcock's direction, because Hitchcock was the master of bringing such characters to life.  Novak and Barbara Bel Geddes (most famous as Miss Ellie on TV's "Dallas") also give excellent performances.Bernard Herrmann's musical score is superlative.  It is beautiful, compelling and chilling and brought additional power to almost every scene.  Hitchcock had such great respect for Herrmann that he stated during production that whether the scenes of the film worked or not depended completely on the music Herrmann would write.  He trusted that Herrmann would create just the right mood, and he was correct.The DVD version presents us with a completely restored version of the film with rich color and powerful sound.  The new DVD is the only way to watch this film if one hopes to experience it the way it was originally presented in 1958.This film is ranked number 61 on AFI's top 100 movies of the century.  I rated it a 10/10.  It was virtually ignored at the Academy Awards garnering only two nominations for set decoration and sound.  However, it endures in the opinion of many as one of the best suspense thrillers ever made.

reviewText: I saw this movie in the theater for the first time while in grad school to study philosophy.  After getting over the shocking ending -- Kim Novak dies! -- I immediately made a connection to the interesting concept from Leibniz of "stepping outside the circle of one's own ideas" and how hard this is to do -- Kant has something similar.  I don't know if Hitchcock ever studied philosophy (he may have) but I think he would have agreed that Leibniz was on to something.  Scotty gets a second chance, a favor that life doesn't grant very often, and he blows it because he's stuck inside the circle of his own ideas.  Judy tries to get him to snap out of it, even playing along with the Madeleine charade, to no avail, proving that if a supremely beautiful woman cannot get thru the "circle," nothing can.  Another key idea in the movie is the importance of knowing when to leave well enough alone, also very hard to do.  Hitchcock was a wise man, no doubt about it, and this movie is definitely his masterpiece.  The restored version looks great.  I hope they'll be showing it in the theater soon on the big screen -- or maybe I need to buy a bigger TV set!

reviewText: Vertigo is an intriguing Hitchcock thriller, set in San Francisco, that has you cheering for Jimmy Stewart as he falls in love and struggles with his fear of heights. Right away you are met with the haunting opening credits and the dramatic opening sequence where Scottie (Stewart) acquires his vertigo. Much of the rest of the film seems surreal with minimal dialogue and interesting cinematography, leading up to the death of Madaleine (Kim Novak). Then the film switches gears and is mostly about the impact on Scottie who had become infatuated with Madaleine. Often he appears to be in a trance and he becomes obsessive after meeting Judy who looks strikingly like Elster's dead wife. Scottie becomes controlling, trying to make Judy into the image of the woman he loved. She just wants him to love her for who she is but that cannot be. Fittingly, the film ends the way it began with drama and tragedy. This certainly is a fascinating view of human psychology and complex emotions. In order to appreciate this film it is almost necessary to watch it twice, once to understand the plot and then another time to spot the little details. Of all of Hitchcock's work, I would say I still enjoy Rear Window or North by Northwest better but this film at least deserves a viewing or two.

reviewText: Oh, how cineastes love this one! Unfortunately, it's almost as if Hitch read all those 50's "Cahiers du Cinema" articles and started taking himself too seriously. The film is self-conscious and artificial, and unlike the director at his best, has absolutely no sense of humor. The fact is that Hitchcock played with "Big Themes" and his own obsessions in many, many of his films, without laying it on with a trowel. Here, there's not only a trowel, but a steamroller. Of course, even 2nd rate Hitchcock has its joys. But there's definitely "less here than meets the eye". If you like your Hitchcock with Freudian overtones, go for "Spellbound" (at least it's campy).
summary: Perhaps the most overpraised of the Hitchcock canon.

reviewText: Jimmy Stewart suffers from vertigo, so of course you get to see some scenes of that.  In 3-D it must have produced dizziness in most of the audience.  In this version it still can make you a little whoozy looking down from a height.  Kim Novak plays two parts very well.  She is Stewart's beloved who dies apparently from suicide.  But did she really?  He thinks so until he sees her double, or is she?  His obsession with the double carries him on a reckless course, finally leading to disaster.  No happy ending here, but the mystery is fascinating.  You won't be able to stop watching it until you figure out the twists and turns.

reviewText: It goes without saying that Vertigo is a five star film. It possesses a haunting emotional power that grabs on and refuses to let go. It is in my opinion the strongest role of one of the strongest actors in cinema history. When Jimmy Stewart falls in love with Kim Novak, we too fall in love. When he is driven mad, we go a little mad with him. Hitchcock's tendencies toward manipulation and artifice have never served a plot better. But, this DVD release does not quite give Vertigo the treatment it deserves. The documentaries feel weak, the commentary is longwinded and transparent in spite of the genius that provides it and the accompanying episode of Alfred Hitchcock Presents is not the best. There's a lot to like about this release, but while Vertigo is a five star film, this DVD is a four star release. I sort of wish Criterion had dealt with this to make the release the shrine it deserves to be.

reviewText: Vertigo is a true classic from the Master, Alfred Hitchcock. Upon its release, Vertigo was not well received by the public or the critics. Since that time it has rightfully started to garner the attention and respect it deserves.The story is good, incorporating drama, suspense, and romance. Vertigo has one of the finest, most gripping, finales I have come across in any motion picture. Even after repeated viewings, the ending still manages to send shivers up my spine.The acting is good all the way around. Jimmy Stewart delivers an absolutely wonderful performance as the slightly disturbed John 'Scottie' Ferguson, a man with a strong fear of heights and an obsession with the mysterious Mrs. Madeleine Elster. Madeleine is played to a cool, smooth perfection by the talented Kim Novak.Robert Burks brings a lot of atmosphere to Vertigo through his cinematography. The colors are vibrant and glowing, giving the film a haunting aura.Bernard Herrmann is at his best, delivering an absolutely riveting and disorienting musical score. The effects for the opening title sequence combined with Herrmann's score really set the tone of the film.Hitchcock's direction is fantastic as always. For this film, he created the infamous "dizzy effect" shot by simultaneously zooming forward and reverse tracking with the camera. This shot has been imitated by many but rarely has it been as effective as it is here.
